original_content:
[Breaking Taps] has a look at parkerization  a process to coat steel to prevent rust. While you commonly see this finish in firearms, it is usable anywhere you need some protection for steel parts. The process is relatively easy. It does require heat and a special manganese solution made for the purpose. You scuff up the surface of the steel and degrease and wash it.
Once the part is ready, you insert the part in hot solution which is manganese and phosphoric acid. Rinse and displace the water and you are ready to oil the part.
But what we really liked was the electron micrographs of the steel before and after the process. The phosphates formed in the solution cover the iron and hold oil to prevent oxidization. However, the first attempt wasnt uniform so it wouldnt work as well. [Breaking Taps] thinks it was a failure to rough up the piece sufficiently before starting. He also raised the temperature of the bath and got a better, but not perfect, result.
We miss having an electron microscope at work and we really want one at home! The last fun coating project we remember used copper in a strange and wonderful way.
title: 鋼鉄の錆びを防ぐパーカライズ工程の魅力
body: 鉄を錆から守るために使われるパーカライズ工程について説明。鉄部品を溶液に浸して表面を保護し、その後油を塗布。元の試みは不均一だったが、温度を上げることで改善。電子顕微鏡での観察や銅を使った面白いコーティングプロジェクトも紹介。
titles: 鋼鉄の錆びを防ぐパーカライズ工程の魅力
溶液を使用して鋼鉄部品を保護する方法
熱と専用のマンガン溶液が必要なハードウェア保護のプロセス
鉄を覆い、錆を防ぐリン酸塩の形成
電子顕微鏡によるスチールの微細な変化を観察
